content: The "Minority Inclusion in Clinical Trials Act of 2015" emphasizes the need to increase representation of underrepresented communities in clinical trials, as stated by the National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants for expanding opportunities for scientists and researchers and promoting the inclusion of underrepresented minorities in health professions. Additionally, support will be provided to institutions committed to workforce development in underrepresented communities. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants to eligible entities, such as educational institutions, that focus on health workforce development in underrepresented communities, including historically Black colleges and universities, Hispanic-serving health professions schools, and tribal colleges and universities. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants to eligible entities, such as educational institutions, that focus on health workforce development in underrepresented communities, including historically Black colleges and universities, Hispanic-serving health professions schools, tribal colleges and universities, Asian-American, Native American, and Pacific Islander-serving institutions, institutions with programs to recruit and retain underrepresented minority health professionals, health professional associations, and institutions located in communities with predominantly underrepresented minority populations. Entities eligible for grants must have at least 20% underrepresented minorities enrolled and submit an application to the Secretary. Funds received are to be used for workforce diversity programs in mental health care professions, including educational outreach programs. The grant programs support various initiatives in the health professions, including scholarships, postbaccalaureate programs, academic enrichment programs, mentoring, internships, community partnerships, and leadership training. Grantees are required to submit annual reports summarizing and evaluating their activities. The term "Asian-American, Native American, and Pacific Islander-serving institutions" is defined in this section. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2015 through 2020. SEC. 5. ELIMINATING DISPARITIES IN MATERNITY HEALTH OUTCOMES. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with various organizations, will conduct research to eliminate disparities in maternal health outcomes. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct research to eliminate disparities in maternal health outcomes. This includes expanding access to services and establishing a demonstration project in up to 8 states to compare interventions and improve maternity care for vulnerable populations. States will be selected based on their applications specifying regions and populations to be served. The Secretary will establish a demonstration project in up to 8 states to improve maternity care for vulnerable populations. Criteria will ensure representation of affected communities, test various models, and involve local provider organizations. The demonstration project for improving maternity care will run from January 1, 2015, to December 31, 2019. States and healthcare providers can receive grants for data collection. States participating in the project must report outcomes, costs, and quality of maternity care to the Secretary. The Secretary will evaluate bundled payments made by states under the project and submit a final report to Congress by December 31, 2020. SEC. 6. HEALTH DISPARITIES EDUCATION PROGRAM. The Secretary will establish a health and health care disparities education program in collaboration with various entities to inform professionals and the public about reducing racial and ethnic disparities. Through public awareness campaigns, the program will target the general public and the medical community. The Secretary will establish a health and health care disparities education program to disseminate scientific evidence and new research findings on racial and ethnic disparities in health care to the general public and medical community. The health and health care disparities education program aims to reduce disparities by disseminating information on linguistic and cultural barriers, data collection on various demographics, providing education to healthcare providers, and assessing program impact. The section focuses on raising awareness of health disparities and providing information on available resources. Authorization of appropriations is granted for fiscal years 2015 through 2020.
